title: EXPAND FEATS TO MORE SCHOOLS High achieving schools Pave the way to success
text:
L ast week was a good week for Savannah Chatham-County Schools to garner state and national recognition for their schools and individual students.
Earlier this week, we lauded the success of the Bartlett STEM Academy for becoming Georgia’s first schoolwide STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) certified middle school.
To earn STEM certification through the Georgia Department of Education, district officials and the faculty and staff at The STEM Academy at Bartlett spent three years developing and implementing an academic program that meets 15 standards proving the school is producing students who can effectively use technology and scientific methods to develop solutions to problems.
We also want to extend congratulations to Garrison Arts K-8 Schools for being named one of nine Georgia public and private schools recognized as 2015 National Blue Ribbon Schools by the U.S. Department of Education on Wednesday.
Each year U.S. Secretary of Education Arne Duncan bestows National Blue Ribbon School honors upon public and private schools that achieve overall academic excellence or close achievement gaps.
“This honor recognizes your students’ accomplishments and the hard work and dedication that went into their success,” Duncan said in a video message to the award recipients. “Your journey has taught you collaboration, intentional instruction, and strong relationships in school and with your community. You represent excellence — in vision, in implementation and in results — and we want to learn as much as we can from you.”
We also want to give a shout out to five promising seventh-grade scholars who have proven their academic prowess to earn REACH Georgia needs-based scholarships. The scholarship went to 330 seventh-grade students throughout the state.
If they meet all of the academic and attendance requirements and graduate from high school on time six years later, the foundation will provide each of them with a $10,000 scholarship to any of Georgia’s HOPE eligible colleges.
Most of those colleges and universities have, in turn, agreed to double or triple the foundation award to cover all tuition costs.
All too often, people are singled out for the bad that they have done. It’s important to recognize achievement to encourage and inspire others. So good job Jahmarion Bacon, Nashay Brooks, Camren Holmes, Dominique Wynn and Jaquin Wynn.
Now the school district must meet the challenge to extend these honors to all students and schools.
The district administration and the elected school board should set their sights on how to give all parents, including those in the inner city, good neighborhood schools. It won’t be cheap and it won’t be easy.
We hope the superintendent and the school board have set aside their past differences because the only way the school district will achieve their goals is by working together. The students at Bartlett, Garrison and the REACH schools have already shown how collaboration leads to success.
